author: donschoe
content: Hello everyone, did we abandon Witti already?

author: donschoe
content: I was hoping to keep this around for a bit ðŸ˜Š

author: arnetheduck
content: would be fun to see what happens when it runs with <64 validators

author: arnetheduck
content: ie when the rest have been ejected

author: donschoe
content: does it require finality to eject validators?

author: donschoe
content: or is it impossible to self-heal once validators shut down?

author: donschoe
content: and if yes, are we entirely betting on the incentive that such a scenario will never happen on mainnet even though it's very unlikely?

author: donschoe
content: what if we see a massive fragmentation due to technical, geographical, or political issues that we do not control?

author: arnetheduck
content: my latest recollection is that the non-ejected validators will form their own finality when that happens and that a "hard" fork is needed to heal such a network split

author: arnetheduck
content: so we're preferring that some network lives on instead of everything grinding to a halt

author: donschoe
content: so, I could just keep my witti nodes running and see what will happen?

author: jonny.derp
content: Why not? It would be interesting to see the inactivity leak work

author: arnetheduck
content: that'll be a fun block to process, the epoch transition where most validators are removed in one big go

author: donschoe
content: ok, I'll check on their health tomorrow

author: ajsutton
content: I'm still running witti validators.  It's been a good verification of the improvement we put in to reduce memory usage during non-finalization.  I'm surprised at how slowly validator balances are dropping though - still going to be a while before we get to kick anyone out.
